This is a pretty simple ferris wheel, but precision tools in MakeVR were really useful in making it look well put-together

To make the concentric circles in the frame, I scaled a cylinder to a very stout shape and then cut into it to remove the entire middle section, leaving only the edges. I then copied it, scaled it up, and then use precision tools to line up the circles exactly. The bars spanning the frame are cylinders rotated on a grid to be precisely 45 degrees apart. The seats/containers were "hollowed out" by making a copy of the bottom piece scaled down and cutting into it using precision tools. The rest of the ferris wheel is carefully eyeballed.

description.text:
My wife makes homemade Oreos every Christmas. This is a simple
stamp to give them the Oreo look.
With a paddle in each hand, a "child" can scrape up the sand for the walls, and at the same time add the tessellation wall patterns for the perfect castle look!

The paddles were designed in Creo 2.0 ... the size of the paddle was decided on by two factors - the print bed of MakerBot Replicator Desktop 3D Printer, and that which would work best for the tessellation pattern of the bricks.

The pattern could be made nice and continuous by overlapping the mortar edges... both on the sides and top/bottom.

A window fit well into a pattern, and makes for a nice external visual... a Door would normally be literally cut into the wall to go through - and would look wrong as a stamping.

I'm just being trained on a 3D printer this week - so I hope maybe my work will let me print a test, to be sure I got the paddle and handle strong enough for real use!
My first 3d Model. A model of my house using tinkercad and some pictures for reference.

This is a tool drawer insert or a parts tray.
Its just a box with the option of a internal arc on the front wall or all walls.
No ramps mean that it has maximum space inside.
Front ramp means that it is easier to get things out.
All ramps mean that it is much easier to get things out.

Put a bunch of them in your toolbox drawer to keep all your bits sorted, or build a couple as mini parts bins.
I have several free ones, and a couple of toolbox drawers that are completely filled with a combination of sizes.

title: Rigidbot single head cooling fan mount

description.text:
NOTICE: See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1381040 for the Rev-2 revision of this design if you have had issues with the mounting tab breaking. Modifications include a wider tab and a strength rib along the edge.

A single fan mount for a stock Rigidbot. The duct blows on the nozzle tip to avoid heater block temperature fluctuations. Requires no additional hardware to mount the duct. Clears the bed by 2 mm and does not touch the rails.

This is simply a modification of my dual head mount with the second head features removed. See the dual head version this was remixed from for the mounting orientation on the carriage and the fan that it uses. The dual fan image above is for reference.

This is a variation on my original dual fan design. Modeling software used was trueSpace 6. The Source STL file will import directly into tS with the scene units in inches and the object units in mm. The Cura STL file is pre-scaled and oriented for printing.

Printing this will require support material to be turned on for best results. I printed the dual fan version with a 0.1 mm layer resolution. It should print in under 4 hours. This resolution results in a very nice snug fit over the extruder mounting plate.

Only the one hex screw needs to be removed and will counter sink back into the hole to lock the fan mount in place.

comments.text: In the images there is a picture of the fan mounted on the dual head version of this cooling fan duct.  It is oriented such that you can read the specs off it.
comments.author: El_Chingon

comments.text: TIP:  When mounting the fans you might need to put a little Teflon tape around the bar.  It will dampen any vibrations from fans that are not perfectly balanced.  Not all fans are manufactured equal.

description.text: A "mech warrior" I made using MakeVR. This was one of my earlier projects, and done without any precision tools. It looks somewhat like an action figure with basic components.

This was my second object, all I really knew do at that point is load in basic shapes, cut them to shapes I wanted, and then glue them together. I developed this spool gear to fit a variety of spools, as I have spools from multiple sources lying around.  The gear is the same as the spool gear on the filament winder by Ian Johnson, with a few adjustments and a cone that starts at 50mm and goes down to 20mm.  
I have designed a replacement hall effect holder but it's still a work in progress.  The bearing holding portion needs a little bit of work, because the bearing is loose by a hair or three.

Assembly includes: 1 5/16 or 8mm threaded rod
1 608zz skate bearing
4 Fender washers
3 5/16 or 8mm nuts The bearing holder / hall sensor mount is designed to fit the Cheap-o hall effect sensor. The magnets are 12mm magnets from a local craft store. I have yet to mount this to the board yet, but I wanted to share this work in progress.

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=955508

Using the following options:

color = blue
text = MATIAS

THIS IS NOT A REAL 3D PRINTED GUN!

Sorry I thought I'd start with the disclaimer since '3D Printed Gun' can cause a bit of fuss at the moment! This gun was created to replicate the classic Marvin the Martian Ray Gun from Looney Tunes, to be used as a prop with a costume. If you glue things in correctly, the trigger actually moves, and the dial on the back to control the size of your KABOOM turns as well. Make sure you slot these parts into position as you glue the 2 halves of the body together, following the exploded view shown in the images.

The parts were split this way to fit on an Up! Plus 2 printer, and minimise support material requirements. Super glue is great for gluing everything together, some undercoat and sanding to clean things up, and a nice yellow spray paint to finish things off.

Read all the details and see photos of the process of 3D printing on my blog https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/2015/08/07/marvin-the-martian-ray-gun-complete/

comments.text: how do you print this? I don't see how the body parts are printable from ANY angle without a ton of support material?
comments.author: Nerys

comments.text: I haven't uploaded these files in any particular orientation - I'm not in the habit of telling people how they should print parts since every printer is different and everyone's needs are different. But in this case yes I did print the body parts in the orientation shown. You will end up with some support material no matter which orientation you print them. The only way to really minimise this is to lay it down with the "ACME" writing on the build plate, then lower the print a bit more to effectively remove the 2 decorative ribs. There would still be some support, but it would certainly be reduced if print time or material waste are a concern.
comments.author: Nerys

comments.text: I just could not find any great orientation. Hence why i asked. :-)
comments.author: edditive

comments.text: Awesome yes I saw @Tobrew who has made one of these merged many of the parts together - at the time of printing this I only had a small Up Plus 2 printer so had to make lots of smaller modular pieces!
comments.author: Nerys

comments.text: I figured that was why. I hate support. really really hate suppport. :-) so I goto great lengths to avoid it when possible even as good as simplify 3d's support is.
comments.author: edditive

comments.text: Nothing fancy to get the print like that, the Up's are just a reliable machine. But the parts were undercoated with a filler and sanded before painting, so this really helped clean things up as well. If you haven't already you can read more of the details on my blog https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/2015/08/07/marvin-the-martian-ray-gun-complete/

title: Watch-style link bracelet with magnetic closure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an update of my previous project Watch Links with 1.75mm Filament pins.

The original project was intended to be an upgraded strap/bracelet for my then wristwatch. That watch has since given up the ghost before I got around to designing a proper adapter link. This time around, it's a standalone bracelet, using neodymium disc magnets to hold the ends closed. It was kind of inspired by the Apple watch's optional magnetic band.

My magnet links are designed to fit a 8mm diameter disc magnet with a height up to ~2.7-2.8 mm.

I had very good results with these settings on my Bukito using PLA:

0.2mm layer height
1mm wall thickness
1mm top/bottom thickness
40mm/s print speed
180C extruder temp

No support or raft needed.

The disc caps should just press-fit over your disc magnet. If the fit feels too loose, feel free to reinforce with your preffered glue.

description.text:
I don't use Kapton Tape any more.

Try this it works fine for me.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=COXb34pJbC8

Get a picture frame from a $2 shop with glass in it, 8 by 10 and some double sided tape. And some cheap hair spray.
Stick glass on build plate. double sided tape.
Check glass clears through out its travel of build plate.
Set build plate level. spay glass and let dry. give a real light spray a few seconds before print, it should be tacky easy.
I run hot build plate at 40 degrees. PLA prints.
I find it prints really really well, big prints within one mill of the edge or little prints all work fine for me.

title: Peterthinks' chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: A little something I'm working on. This chain is threaded onto filament, wire or elastic cord instead of linking together with little nubs like most chains (which kinda sucks in my opinion). Still needs some work on the ends but that's specific to my printer design. The chain itself is good to go. Modify the ends to suit your needs. I suppose filaflex would be good for stringing it together but regular PLA seems to work. Insulated 16 AWG copper wire works great too. The Sketchup files are included so you can modify it as needed. There is almost no limit to how long you can make this since it won't pop apart. The tolerance is very forgiving too since you can clean up the spine holes with a drill. If your printer can spit out plastic you can make this.

Thread your wire or plastic thru the holes looping it back thru the top bit around the mounting bolt hole. A knot at either lose end and/or a dab of glue in the spine tube keeps it attached to the base plate part. I'm going to use some nice flexible multi strand wire for my chain spine. I'm not sure how filament will hold up in the long run being bent over and over, it seems like PLA will work but if it gets brittle with age it's gonna fail.

So the idea is to tie thin string across the build area and print the teethes or bars across them. a good idea probably is to print a bottom part first and after adding the string print the top half. by printing some relevant fixtures on the table extended lengths can be obtained by advancing the chanin after the print by a given length and continue the print further down the strings.
Has someone tried to do print with object locked inside a pocket like a nut or some thing that is added half way?

comments.text: why not print roller chain? print plates(same for inner and outer links) and bushings. pins would be plastic filament. you could forgo the string and just print simple parts with no spacing requirements, some assembly required though.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: the issue of maintaining perfectly even spacing between gears is an issue. One idea would be to make it so that you print the pieces in sets of 5 or 6 and each is printed with a thin (maybe 2 layers) surface connecting them(just a string of plastic really). That way, you could attach the string as you describe (though I think two small sides that snap/glue together would actually be easier) then simply snap the thin connectors away. You could then be assured that there is correct spacing between the bars.
comments.author: letsburn00

comments.text: You would need to print past the holes first as the nozzle would scrape any string off the table unless its recesses already.    might design it as two snap together shells.?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Yes ill address that in an animated illustration that i will post soon. by printing the bottom half  with a narrow channel, then adding the strings, and finally print the top half
comments.author: Guest

title: Simply Auto bed with Capacitive proximity AND ONLY a 12V relay

description.text:
Looking on the web I have only found auto bed solutions with the use of some resistors to low the output voltage of the sensors, or with the use of a optcoupler.
Bu I have though "Can I use the output of the proximity to pilot a 12V relay?"
Well it can be done. In the file there is a simple diagram too.
The sensor 12V input are the same of the ramps. The signale out of the sensor pilot a 12V relay.
The Com pin of the relay is the S pin of the Z min, and the NO pin of the relay is the "-" pin of the z-min.

yeah I know that in my printer there is a lot of spave between the sensor and the hotend :D
I have to change that part. But it works. With just a relay and the sensor ;)

Here you can find a video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NRFidCOjpvI
and here my post on my blog (sorry only italian... you can use google translator ^^)
http://www.indiegearlab.com/autobed-levelling-ljc18a3-h-zby-semplice-e-rapido/2358

comments.text:
hello
as the relay consumes in ma ? because it all the time under tension during printing? sorry for english)
comments.author: dolphin_max

comments.text:
Sorry for the delay.
I don't remember well but I think the relay and the proxy abosorb very low current...
something like 0.5A together I think.
If you want something better you shoul have another relay to turn on the sensor only during the autobed procedure.
comments.author: dolphin_max

comments.text: You loose some precession when using a relay as it does not switch instantly. Personally I use an optocoupler because the voltage divider was to risky for me with my Smoothieboard.
comments.author: fishbyte

comments.text:
Yeah I know that it's not 100% precise.
But for my application it works fine.
And to gain precision i think I could always decrease the z-axis speed.
comments.author: fishbyte

comments.text: Could just use a voltage divider
comments.author: StealShot

comments.text:
Yes I could, but I didn't want to use a volta divider.
I don't like very much that solution. I like the relay solution more. Yeah I know that a relay is generally more expensive than the voltage divider, but I find it more simple in my opinion.
tastes are tastes :)
comments.author: StealShot

Notes:

The cover is facing upwards in the stl which will requires a lot more support if you flip it upside down. But since the support is not easy to completely cleanup, I will choose to have cleaner appearance.
After printing, remove all the supports and I use some super glue to put the buttons on the cover. For the PI, use self-tapping M2 or M2.5 to install.

title: 3D Printer extruder nozzel  Level Gauge for 2 and 3 extruder printers

description.text:
I built this to make it easier to get the three nozzle tips at exactly the correct high on my 3 extruder printer. Its works really well for leveling the print bed as well.

This is a work in progress.
I wouldn't print the pointers on the next round because they warp and are not easy to print. I will make a side clamps so I can clamp on some needles on each sides which will be more accurate to read as well.

Please double check the integrity of files before printing this. I had some issue where some layers were "weird" so did a reprint.

ABS 3mm
Layer high 0.1
Shell 1
Print speed 60
Fill Density 50%

author: BB1980

title: Arduino Nano case with completely accessible pins

description.text:
This is a two-part case for Arduino Nanos or clones of it (as featured in the pictures). It is similar to a design by spradlinb, but made from sketch.

Features

  • The two halves just clip together, if printed with the right clearance (see Instructions)
  • USB port accessible
  • All top and bottom pins accessible as far as the plastic part of the pin headers
  • Top 6 pins do not protrude from the case
  • Arduino board is held in place by four small pillars

The Arduino Nano 3D model was created by Andrew Whitham (https://grabcad.com/library/arduino-nano--1).

The bottom part can be printed normally.

For the top part that clips on the bottom part, there are several versions:
For example NANOCASE-top-0.05.stl is for an interference fit with 0.05 mm overlap. The file with +0.05 has a positive clearance of 0.05 mm.

On my Flashforge Creator Pro, 0.05 mm overlap and 0.2 mm layer height worked fine.

The PRT files were created with Siemens NX 9.

Font_name = Chewy
Rotation = 65

Prince Teng Pavilion is located in Nanchang, Jiangxi, China. It was built in Tang Dynasty in memory of Li Yuanying, which is the brother of the king. It is famous for the Tengwanggexu from the poet Wang Bo.

I built this model with Cinema 4D. I designed this to be a lamp at first. I printed it with 1mm thick and support using a delta bot. The printing speed is 40.

I designed it with Cinema 4D. I have been there once. I built this model by reffering pictures and memory. The ancient Chinese buildings are very complex in structure. I simplified some of the structures such as the part under the roof.

The model is printed by a delta bot with 0.1mm thick and support of course.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9REQO6kf2eq
A Vacuum Cannon, that will launch printable projectiles to near the speed of sound. https://vimeo.com/135655056

Besides the printable parts, you will need :
--Single stage vacuum pump.
--Acrylic tube ID=40mm OD=50mm.
--Vacuum tube.
--Packing tape min 50mm wide.
--Eye and ear protection!

Using the cannon:
Insert a projectile in the end with the hose connector.
Add one or two layers of packing tape at each end, depending on tape type, and desired pressure. If using two layers apply them perpendicular to each other.
Remove anyone or anything at either end of the tube.
Lower the pressure with a vacuum pump, single stage is sufficient.
Puncture the packing tape in the end with the hose connector with a sharp knife, POP!

Printing the end caps:
Print them with thick walls or 100% infill to make them strong and air tight. Glue them on the ends of the acrylic tube. Remove the print support under the hose connector.

Printing the projectiles:
This is trial and error. I printed them single walled, with 4% infill. In Cura you can move the projectile around on the build plate so that you get two perpendicular infill walls exactly in the middle. This way they will weigh around 7g, and be quite strong.

Customizer:
The end caps are customizable for any tube ID/OD.
The bullets are not yet customizable, but you can easily make your own.

Disclaimer: This build is intended for physics professors or similar teaching physics. It will accelerate the projectile to speeds near the speed of sound. I am not responsible for any injuries you inflict on yourself, others or things.

Vacuum Cannon

title: Star Wars AT-AT Driver 1980 Figurine Bust v2.0

description.text:
Star Wars AT-AT Driver 1980 Figurine Bust.  
Made using Autodesk 123D Catch, Blender and Solidworks.  
A series of photographs was taken around the original figurine, complete with dirt, grime and scuffs. Autodesk 123D Catch takes the photographs and produces an approximate 3D model which can be exported. Solidworks was used to create the plinth and wrapped text. Both .STL files were then imported into Blender and assembled.  
Expect more accurate models using the same techniques soon.
Single part, perfectly flat on base. Just scale and print.

description.text:
Cable Chain Management parts for the Prusa i3 :

These are mostly re-works or improvements made on some things found & adapted for the Prusa i3 & as such are a work in progress.

Revised & strengthened version of Chain Link by bqLabs :

  • Original Drag Chain : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:397273

Link Bed Mount : Hash up of two other bits ... ( got find them again )

  • Wire Guide : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44836
  • Link Bed Mounts : Straight, Left & Right 90 deg Returns ...

Link Y Axis Coupling : revised ...

  • link to go in here ...

Link X Axis Coupling : modified version of ...

  • X Axis Motor with cable chain mount : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:832436

Link Motor Mount : Modified from this as a Trial for Chain Links ...

  • Inline Cable Chain connector : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:290798/#files

There's a few other bits for this, will add as I find them ... :)

Cheers, Bantum ...

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Fine

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Some parts may require support & rafts as required ...
Re-works were mostly done in SketchUp, with continuity check done in netfabb ...

Print out the bits as you need them ...

  • Chain links : Can be printed in multiples & should be easy to put together ...
    Note : Trick is to align the thinnest section at one end & squeeze it into other at a slight angle ( may need pliers to assist ) ... Tip : Lots of Links needed ... :)

  • Link Bed Mount : Clip mounts to support frame of carriage ( will post a photo later ) There are Two versions, one straight & the other with a 90 deg. return. So depending on how you have wired yours, should work ok with either way.

  • Y Axis Link Coupling : This may require reworking as have yet to fit correctly ... Edit : have now fixed this & uploaded new version ...

  • Motor mounts : Yet to work on these ...

Install as required - Feed those wires ... ;)

( More to add here later )

Cheers, Bantum...

Re-works of the Cable Chain to be found on here some where : It has the same external dimensions as the original, so should still fit the old system - just tweaked it a bit to strengthen it up ... :)

  • Increased the overall thickness. ( 2mm )

  • Internal dimensions will be less than before ( haven't measured it yet ).

Edits :
Aug 2015 :

  • Made up a draft version to connect chain link to printer bed - yet to get this to work ...

  • I've added a shortened 'Left Return' for the Link Bed Mount, as the other was too long & facing the wrong way ... ;)

Sept 2015 :

  • Added Link Motor Mount & X Axis Coupling - both are works in progress & have yet to print these ...

title: M3D Horizontal overhead filament holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I came up with this design to create a stable filament holder that could hold a full 1kg spool on top of the M3D Micro printer, rather than behind.

Print 4 legs (they only just fit on the M3D and need to be positioned diagonally across the print bed!) and one of everything else - the legs friction fit into the centre, and the weight of the spool keeps everything nicely in place without any gluing!

Obviously you'll need to use a high level of infill as there'll be a fair bit of weight on these parts.

This stand can be used in two ways - either with the rotor plate assembled with 4 skateboard bearings (size 608), or without the rotor as a non-rotational stand.

In the non-rotational configuration, feed the filament from the spool through the hole in the centre and into the print head. The filament will then pull from the spool without the spool needing to rotate - I've had limited success with this so far, and prefer the rotation mode personally

In the rotating mode, place an old CD/DVD (that you don't care about the data on) on top of the rollers to provide a smooth platform for the spool to rotate on. It's also recommended to use a couple of the filament guides to keep the filament feeding along the line of the cable - see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746048 for a suitable part.

All the parts are sized to be printable on the M3D Micro, although the legs needs to be printed along the diagonal axis of the printer.

There's a few more parts to come for this, including a centring hub and extension shaft to help keep the rotating spool centered and balanced - I'm testing these parts now before I release them!

Update - new version of the leg which now hopefully lies flat on the print bed.

Update - 14-Sep-15 - Spool centering cone is now here - this can be inserted into the top of a spool to centre it on the shaft - for tall spools an extension piece to increase the height of the centre tube

Update 17-Sep-15 - I've added a couple of extra photographs to show how this is assembled, with the rotor plate sat on top and the bearings hanging over the side. Then the DVD you don't care about should be placed on-top to provide a stable turntable for your filament.

Update 3-Nov-15 - I've added a new design for the filament support arm - which now has two holes - I've found the feeding works better if the takeoff from the spool goes through the top hole in one arm, and the larger slot in the next arm before heading into the print head.

Also, loose filament can be handled by using 4 support arms as a cradle, then feeding the filament through the centre hole of the tower (see new photo)

Update 6 Jan 16 - New centre for tabletop use (without the M3D printer underneath and the legs) has now been uploaded

description.text:
El verano es muuuuuy laaaaargo y hay que entretener a los cachorros. Os pongo una chorradita que he hecho para jugar a los espías y a los mensajes cifrados. De momento solo he sacado una plantilla, pero la idea es hacer 3 o 4 modelos distintos. Los niños se lo pasan pipa, y al tiempo hacen algo de "tarea".
Pongo el fichero excel para generar las matrices cifradas (automatizado) y el fichero de autocad por si alguien quiere personalizarlo un poco.
Creo que voy a reducir un pelín el tamaño de la matriz, ya que sale un peco grande (para niños pequeños como los míos va bien).

title: Temple to the Holy Water bottle

description.text: We bless the great bottle of water and we honor it by filling this mold with sand and creating temples for this holy one. Many linear patterns and geometric shapes such as triangles and squares are blessed for aiding in the design of this mold. A great many shells are recommended in the honoring of The Water, and may you riddle the beaches with Its' glory!

Some reorientation of the parts are required. The different halves are required for the temple, but the full temple is not. The file is included anyway. Print with a high number of shells, and a relatively low infill. DO NOT USE SUPPORTS. AGAIN, DO NOT USE SUPPORTS. All parts are designed to bridge. Rafts may be helpful. Once both halves are printed, there shall be 19 thin supports. Those should be cut off. be cut off. Once Those are off, fill the molds and start riddling the beaches with Its' honor!

author: Brooksola

description.text:
I enjoyed creating the stacking El Castillos so I decided to make stacking Moais!

Moais are giant stone statues carved by the Rapa Nui people on Easter Island. They are mainly the faces of ancestors. Most of the statues are found in Rano Raraku, the main Moai Quarry. The others were transported to the perimeter of the island.

Happy printing!
Scale down (or up) each iteration by 70%. You should be able to print all of them in one go if you position them correctly.

A handheld toy that holds two double helix involute gears and lets you spin them.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=StVKFPdXqrw
Designed in OpenSCAD. Printed at 0.2mm with 15-20% infill for the gears, and 30-50% infill for the base (for strength so the shafts don't break off so easily.)

title: Statue of Liberty - Repaired
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The head is fixed now!!!! thanks Joao please print an post a picture
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3qFesRik4uI
Note: Please LAY FLAT when printing, AND USE SUPPORTS. The ideal size for the model is the size uploaded, or 20% smaller. Please read instructions on how to assemble. Check out all the pics!

The amazing Statue of Liberty from New York!
Amaze friends, family, teachers, and even pets with this awesome replica. It was printed from a flash forge printer from "Kens Hub"

Tips - use the uploaded size, avoid scaling down, or up too much. The uploaded size has been found ideal after numerous attempts.

  • Use the highest resoultion available on your printer. this will result in the best print
  • Use SUPPORTS ON ALL PIECES, this will make the book and torch and face come out much nicer - AVOID RAFTS, if you do use rafts, do a good job of removing them and make sure your gluing surfaces are clean and smooth

Please watch the video as well.

  1. Print one of each part.
  2. Make sure the flat part is flat on the building platform.
  3. Apply supports when printing
  4. Once the parts have been printed, an adhesive will be required to assemble it. I recommend a 15 - 30 min epoxy that will not dissolve the material you used to print. I used PLA and it worked great.
  5. Apply a thin blob of glue to the model of the flat gluing surfaces of each part and spread. For example the top part of the "Liberty Feet" which is a flat surface.
  6. Stick the "main body" to the "feet"
  7. Attach the "head" to the top of the main body". Make sure everything is aligned.
  8. Align the "torch top" and "bottom" so the hand portion is distinctive and you can see the fingers come together.
  9. Glue the torch and hand portion to the top of the arm ( the arm is part of the "liberty head')
  10. Let the epoxy cure. Now you have a great Statue of Liberty Replica model! leave a comment

No

Yes

Fine

Solid

( as per illustration )
Re-works were done in SketchUp, with continuity check done in netfabb ...

I had trouble with original version which kept on braking - so have modified it to strengthen some of the weak points & improve overall design.

  • Print out as many will fit on your printer - as you'll need quite few ... ;)

  • Remove flashing / supports & join together to form chain ...

  • Feed the wiring through as required ...

Tip : Tape the ends of wire together & temporarily remove any plugs to enable smooth passing through the links ...

Enjoy, Bantum ...

Do note there may be a small compile error in this file, but doesn't seem to affect the overall performance - so will leave it alone for now ( unless someone has suggestions for further improvements ) ... :)

I may come back to revise this later from test results ...

  • Tweaked the Drag Chain Link - as I found first edition doesn't quite turn through 45 deg - have uploaded a revised edition with fixes ...

Ciao, Bantum ...

title: K8400 Vertex Spool Mount Holder Remix

description.text:

As I already used the remixed Spool Mount Holder by bartkoopman it was not so far fetched to add a couple of holes so I could place a spool further away at a corner bracket. I throw in a more printer friendly Spool Holder Base too. IT IS NOT TESTED! If you want to get rid of the support I made, just split the object.

And get rid of the two outer nuts on the spool mount, they will only make the ball bearing jam (pic3).

Cheers!

description.text:
After adding the extruder arm to move the extruder about 25% closer to the hot end the original filament dispenser did not work.

I made this to fit a PVC pipe I had in the garage. It has an OD of 22.5mm I believe it is electrical conduit. The current design will work with anything up to 37mm tube. Smaller tubes will place the roll closer to the surface. It holds a 133mm long tube.

I make this for the Kickstarter version of the DeltaPrintr the website version may need slight adjustments.

The design has a few slight modifications from my original print to accommodate larger size tubes and raise the roll a little higher.

I designed the dispenser to use horizontal bars but I don't think they are necessary. The holders fit pretty snugly onto the top of the printer. I have included two variations for your printing pleasure.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit on line.
Holder: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kIB45yZUNy5
Bars: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eMuw2qLzJOV

I printed at 25% fill and it is plenty solid.
I used the design with horizontal bars and forgot to use any support. Took a little filing to clean up the joints.

Print two of the holders. And if using the one with horizontal bars then print two bars.

comments.text: The bars are quite a tight fit, but once their on (with the help of pliers), it's a rock solid spool holder. Thank you very much for this, i should have printed this a lot earlier...

If you wanted to make a sand castle with a Science, Technology Engineering, Art and Mathmatics then you are about to start printing! With only a handful of shapes you can create complex biuldings! This print is a day at the beach. Using simple geometric shapes you can mold and sculpt your imaginations best sand castle but that's not all you can measure your castle or other sand structures volume. With our linear function you can find the volume of your creation.

Imagine rising towers and turrets to defend against invading hordes! A great wall surrounding your fortress.The simple shapes include the cube (100ml), pyramid (30ml), parabola (35ml) and my favorite the hexagonal prism with a volume of 75ml.
Scale them up or down, I made them at the factory size. Also print the hand tools so you can sculpt the sand to your specifications.

The pattern maker will let you put every thing from emblems to fractals on your castles buildings, roads and walls. And after you are done place the JMAP emblem plate on to your castle so every one else can know that they can get there castle making kit on Thingiverse!

The reason I decided to enter this Challenge is because my printer is starting to fall apart, well has fallen apart and I need a new printer. I don't have it in my budget to get another one so this contest is my only hope. I have my own LLC and I at the moment am going to school. Having a printer let's me solidify my thoughts. I can make my prototypes and equipment into plastic. Without the technology I will no longer be able to do this. I also make custom items and sell them and a 3d printers is a must. I believe that every one should be able to create and build, Improve and create and with work and endurance you can create what you imagine!

I included two sets of thick walled and thin walled so that you can chose which one you want. And this is just the beginning get ready for more molds!

90% infill

The formula for determining volume is,

F(x)= XY

X=Volume of default shape and Y= Scale factor such as 1.00 or 2.00.

For the rolling pattern use supports up on the bottom.

comments.text:
iff you scale it down a bit it fits on any print bed equal to or above 15x15x15 (cm) !
by scaling it down you also reduce the "air tightness" and the object will become printable !
a good tip

I created this thing in 123D Design. Print this 90°Rotated so you don't need any support.
